participant.affiliation: Director, Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer
Director, President and Chief Executive Officer
Director, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer
Tudor Pickering Holt & Co. Securities, Inc.

plist.p: ...this last shipment, it include crude oil natural gas is [Technical Difficultly] now I'll turn it over to Randy.
Excuse me, just say it Regina.
Yes, sir.
Can you hear me?
I can right now.

Okay. Well apparently we're having a bad reception here, nobody can hear the calls. So we thought about maybe hanging up and trying to – and have everybody stay on the line and we would redial from our end.
That's fine. Your line actually stands by, right now the other speakers have not been .
Okay. Have not point been clear. It's been clear, it's a good on this mic, but it's not good on those.
Can you hear on this mic?
What you just said down is clear, yes.
All right.

All right, we'll pick up and we'll also work to do later with this is – we'll see it, if we can come back in and maybe get a clearer recording of the comments that Mike and Jim have and get those posted out there later. So, you can pick those. Returning to the income statements and some other

items G&A cost decreased $8 million this quarter from the second quarter of 2011 primarily due to lower employee cost inflation and tax related expenses. Bottom of the note G&A costs for the second quarter of 2011 included about $2.5 million worth of expenses with respect to the merger of with DEP and also expenses associated with EPE.

In terms of interest expense it decreased $2 million quarter-to-quarter primarily due to lower expenses related to interest rate hedging activity and higher capitalized interest. In terms of capitalized spending, we spent $927 million in CapEx this quarter, which includes about $837 million of growth capital of the joint deal which was for Eagle Ford related to our development project. We spent $1.8 billion in growth capital expenditures during the first six months of the year. We can expect to expand approximately $3.8 billion over the year. Decline in CapEx was $90 million in the second quarter of 2010, $180 million for the first half of the year, we still believe we will .

Adjusted EBITDA for the 12 months ended June 30, 2012, was $4.3 billion. Our consolidated leverage ratio to debt principal to adjusted EBITDA was 3.3 times for the 12 months ended June 30, 2012. That's after adjusting debt for for the hybrid debt securities. The average life of our debt is 12 years if we use the first call date for the hybrids; our . At June 3, we had consolidated liquidity of approximately which included availability under our credit facility as well as cash.
Randy, I will turn back to you.
, we are ready to take questions now.
We are ready to take questions now. Randy said while ago that .
[Management Discussion Indiscernible]
Your first question will come from the line of Darren Horowitz with Raymond James.

Hey, guys. Good morning. I don't know if you can hear me or not, but we'll go ahead and fire away. Jim, two quick questions, the first, referencing that recent rebound in NGL prices that you talked about, how do you think about hedging your equity NGL volumes out of Meeker and Pioneer into the back half of this year? And I guess it's really more of a question around how you think about balancing the ability to lock in those C2 prices to get that cash flow certainty versus trying to maximize your P&L exposure by effectively being long Rockies ethane and selling Belvieu to lock in that attractive spread (25:40)?
I don't have a clue what you're asking, Rob. Was that Rob?
No, it's Daren.
Daren, I don't have a clue what you're asking. I think what you're saying is what do we think about locking in for the second half of the year?

Well, you've got. I mean, I think out of the Rockies, correct me if I'm wrong, out of Meeker and Pioneer, you're mostly hedged on C3+, but you've had a bounce back in C2 ethane pricing. So I guess it comes down to whether or not you think about locking in C2 prices at this stage of game for the next six months or if you just want to be as long as you can Conway or Rockies ethane and sell Belvieu?

What we are looking – we're not locking-in at these prices the second half of the year on ethane. What we're looking at, frankly, is any time we – I think we're 35% hedged on ethane in the third quarter. And we don't have any hedges on in the fourth quarter. But go back to the statement, if you could hear us – hear me, it's the first earnings call I've had where Mike and I just talked to ourselves.
But we enjoyed it.

Yeah. If you all didn't hear us, it was was dynamite, let me tell you. If you look at, Daren, how we run our system, right now, we've been one of the guys that have rejected ethane in the Rockies primarily because, I got a strong look from the lawyer here, primarily because we could make more money buying ethane in Conway and move it to Mount Belvieu in that pipeline capacity that we control on Mid-America and Seminole being our allocated capacity. So if we can buy ethane or propane in Conway at $0.30 plus a gallon times off of Mount Belvieu, that's better than making $0.10 a gallon on our ethane out of the Rockies. Does that help?

No, it does Jim, and I appreciate it. What's your thought process on how that spread plays out through the back half of this year, especially when you start looking at the propane inventory situation? And I think that you talked a little bit about that in your prepared commentary, even though it sounded like you were basically giving the call while scuba diving. But to the extent that propane inventories keep a lid on ethane prices, do you still think that that Conway to Belvieu spread remains about $0.25?

Well, I don't know what it remains. I think there's going to be a product in Conway that we're going to be able to move to Mount Belvieu and take advantage of a pretty wide spread, be it ethane, propane, or normal butane, frankly. Does that help, Daren?

No, it does. And then last question, Jim, from a longer-term perspective, when you think about the Mid-America Rockies NGL pipeline expansion, and on the back end of that, what Texas Express does for you, how much of a leg up do you think it gives you to allow Rockies and Mid-Con producers in order to get their EP down to Belvieu and get Belvieu pricing?

Well, I think once we bring Texas Express out, and I think there's a – there may be some other pipe coming in. We don't pay attention to the others. I think it will have a – it will have the impact of relieving some of that downward pressure on Conway relative to Mont Belvieu. You've got to admit, you got to remember though, Oneok is building a pipe I think out of the Bakken down into Conway, tying it into Overland. So, you know, it depends on what new supplies hit Conway. Theoretically, it ought to relieve some of the pressure.
Yeah, I appreciate it, Jim. Thanks.
Your next question comes from the line of Brian Zarahn with Barclays.
Good morning.
Good morning, Brian.
I'm not sure, Randy may have mentioned it, but the connection was a little choppy. On CapEx for 2012, did you say $3.8 billion?
Yes, Brian.
Okay. And then on 2013, is sort of a similar level a reasonable expectation at this point?
Yeah. Based on the projects that we have in hand now, I think Brian, probably the range is between $3.5 billion and call it $3.8 billion.

Okay, on the PDH unit, it won't be in service for a couple of years, you do have the majority of it subscribed, what – around 75% I believe, what level do you expect to be contracted before it comes online?
Turn your microphone (30:43)

Okay. And in terms of the returns, because this is a little different type of asset for you, what type of expected returns would it be for this project for the PDH Unit, would it be in line with sort of other type of NGL-related projects or maybe a little higher?

It's going to meet our expectations. I'm going to go back to Jerry's question, what Jerry told you – we are not fully contracted, we are contracted to the point that we're happy with the return if we don't get anymore. But the reality is we got several companies wanting the rest of this capacity, we don't think we're going to have any trouble contracting it, and we think the returns are going to be very nice for us.

And Brian, we typically don't give returns on our projects. But as Jim said, this is a good project in and of itself, and it fully integrates into a lot of our other assets and so it's a very attractive project.
Okay, and then last one from me. The onshore crude business was very strong this quarter, can you talk some of the drivers, was it more marketing oriented or was it a combination of factors?

Yeah, Brian, this is Mark. It's a really a combination of factors, one is the increased production in the areas where we are, South Texas, West Texas in particular. And so we're getting more transportation revenue, fee based revenue. And then the marketing business was pretty strong in the second quarter. And that really is, our marketing business benefits from a very nice spread between LLS and WTI, and that spread was better in the second quarter than it was in the first quarter.
Thanks, Mark.
Your next question comes from the line of Ross Payne with Wells Fargo.
How you doing, guys?
Hey, Ross.
First question is, can you talk about the changes in processing contracts migrating towards fee based, and what your current blend of fee based, POP and keep-whole might be as a percentage?
Randy, you know? We keep doing that.

Yeah, hey Ross, this is Randy. Currently we're about, with the second train of Yokum expected to come on this month, we are currently at about 30% keep-whole and expect that number to come down as the third train or last train of Yokum comes on next year. I'm looking at, actually it's lower than that, it's about 21%, 20%, 21% right now.
Okay, and the percentage of fee and POP, if you have it?
Yeah. The combination would be -
I think what he's asking is to break them out separately, Randy.
Okay.
Yeah. The percent of proceeds or percent of NGLs would be about 28% and then pure fee would be 32%. And that's today.

Great. And it was kind of breaking up on Mike and Jim earlier, but if you could talk about your hedges for the second half and what you might be looking at for 2013 for your equity NGLs and natural gas?

I think, Ross, on C3+, I think we're 75%, 80% hedged through the balance of the year. On ethane, we're about 35% hedged in the third quarter. We don't have any hedges on in the fourth quarter, and we're not thinking about next year yet.
Okay. All right.
Well – we – we, on C3+, I guess we are over-hedged.
Okay. And then the final question is in the crude pipeline write up. I assume too that that profit increase was a result of the Seaway reversal as well, is that fair to say?
Yeah. We started to get some Seaway revenue in June.
Okay.
But Ross, that was only a part of a quarter, so it didn't have a full quarter impact.
Got you. So we'll see more of that next quarter. Okay.
I sure hope so.
All right, great. Thanks, guys.
Thank you, Ross.
Your next question comes from the line of Steve Maresca with Morgan Stanley.
Hey, good morning everybody.
Good morning, Steve.

I apologize if I ask something you went over. I – it was really, really difficult to hear, so on the PDH plant, so you got 75% contracted. You want to get to 100%, so will you not have any sort of margin exposure? Is the idea that everything will be locked in with these agreements?
There'll be no commodity risk for enterprise on this project whatsoever.

Okay. Okay, on the propane exports, can you talk about where you think you'll be on where you'll be once the expansions are done in terms of export capacity? I guess, what you think you'll be exporting by the end of this year?
I think what we've been said is, we'll have about 7.5 million barrels a month of capacity, is that about right, Al?
Yeah.

Okay, and what we've been doing, we're fully contracted next year, but we need to put that in context. One of the things we did, I'm going to look at Al Martinez, one of the things we do is we leave a spot a month open. Is that right, Al?
Correct.

You can get your butt in there. We leave a spot a month open in the event we have some issues we don't want to domino and out. But then typically what we've been able to do is we get to that month, we're able to do a spot deal. Those deals are typically quite a lot higher in terms of fees than our contracts are. So we're fully contracted based on what we want to contract, and we have about a spot a month that is available for spot deals.
Correct. We contract to the full operational efficiency of the dock during the month, and then take advantage of the optimization during the month.
When you say a spot a month, can you quantify, what does that mean in terms -
One cargo is approximately 550,000 barrels.
Okay.
And typically, we've been able to fill that at some pretty nice fees on a spot basis.

Okay. Okay, that's helpful. And then my, I guess my last one, on the NGL pipeline services segment, so you had equity NGL volumes were down to 96,000 barrels a day from 120,000. You said 10,000 of it was due to lower ethane recoveries. Can you talk about the remainder of the weakness for the decline?
I think we're going to have to get back to him on that.

Yeah, Steve, I think probably two areas may have been impacted. You may have had – you also had some downtime offshore in the Gulf of Mexico with some production platforms being worked over. That would have impacted the Louisiana processing volumes. And then to a degree, you may just have – just with the lower drilling activity up in Wyoming, you do have some depletion up around that Jonah Pinedale field.
Okay.
Okay. Thanks, everybody.
Okay.
Your next question comes from the line of Ted Durbin with Goldman Sachs.

Thanks. We were just talking bigger picture, you guys have started to introduce a graph on some of your presentations on overall supply demand for the next five years. I'm wondering if you can just walk through some of the major assumptions that go into that, whether it's rig count, decline rate from the supply side – especially on the supply side, really?

Yeah, I think you hit it. We try – the hardest thing is to try to figure out what the decline rate is, but we're looking – we have a pretty good reservoir group. We're looking at all the different basins, we try to understand what the richness is of the gas. We look at rig counts and come up with what we think the supply will be around those assumptions.
Care to add any specificity to the assumptions?
We look at your typical analyst reports.
Fair enough, the – let's just shifting topics here, just come back to the PDH piece, do you expect that to be qualifying income, and if not, I'm assuming you've baked that into economics?

We do think it's qualifying income, and we have an opinion from a big law firm to that effect. But there's also another partnership out there that has a PDH facility that apparently got comfortable with its qualifying income as well.

Got it. The – just a little on some of the detail stuff, the octane enhancement was a pretty strong quarter here, it looks like it was more than just a seasonal bump, is that true or was there anything special going on there?
Just had, globally, we had strong demand for MTD, and prices reflected that. Some other averages in terminals around the world affect the prices here.
We've had a couple of – we've had good years in a row, I think, on that plant.

Yeah, okay, fair enough. And then the last one from me, just on the Independence Hub here, the volume is down, there's no chance this sort of re-contract, you had the re-contract roll off after the last quarter, there's no more re-contracting we should expect there. You'll just be sort of subject to the volumes by whatever the volumes show up out there?
Yeah. It's really dependent on the drilling activity around in that region in the Gulf, and so, which is of course mainly driven by gas price.
And Ted, the contract didn't roll off, this contract is still there, there was a demand charge, if you will, for the first five years, so that piece of it will (41:15)
Got it, okay. That's it for me, guys. Thanks.
Your next question comes from the line of Bradley Olsen with Tudor Pickering.
Hi. Good morning, guys.
Good morning.

So propane export economics remain very favorable, and when you think about kind of the capacity that you have right now and some of the capacity coming online from third parties over the next year to 18 months, would you be interested in further expanding your capacity, given those favorable economics?

Well, you can only expand the extent that you have export quality propane, and what drove the size of this expansion was the amount of export quality propane that we have. In other words, you can't have as much ethane in the propane, you've got to produce to 2% to 2.5% ethane. And that – this expansion reflects our capability from our fractionators and our splitters to produce the volume of propane needed to support the expansion.
Yeah, for further expansion to export, we would have to expand our ability to produce low ethane propane for export.
Given the spread between global prices and U.S. prices right now, are the economics there to consider expanding your ability to fractionate that export quality propane?
You know, I've never had a problem with a full S (42:40).
And certainly Bradley, the more capacity you build, the lower the fees get for that, so that there is a balance there some place.
Yeah, and that balance is around your ability to – it really goes back to what your supply capability of low ethane propane.

Okay. That makes sense. We've seen some valuations – I guess, valuations have maybe come off a little bit in the midstream market, especially among some of your smaller cap peers. In the past, you guys have talked about organic opportunities being more attractive than M&A. Has – have any of the valuations you've seen changed your opinion on that?

Yeah, given our CapEx for the balance of this year and for next year, and frankly for some projects that we're looking at, that may be out in 2014, 2015, we're very happy with the organic growth. We still think that even though some prices have come down, they've come down for a reason for those entities, and so they still look too attractive to us on a M&A basis compared to what we can do internally.

Great, that's helpful. And I guess this question comes back to some of your comments earlier on the PDH unit, specifically around the opinion you received from your lawyers. It seems like there's a little bit more willingness or a little bit more flexibility around petro chemical assets than I think maybe investors and folks in the market kind of considered non-MLP qualifying assets in the past. Now that it seems that there is kind of more of a door opening to ethane crackers and PDH units being put in, how does that change your kind of forward view about could this grow into either a substantial business where you're operating petrochemical assets for maybe a petrochemical customer who's taking the commodity risk, are their more opportunities similar to the PDH unit?

I think that we looked at PDH pretty hard, we think that that's a nice fit, we looked at butadiene. We did get a letter ruling that butadiene, I don't think that (44:52) butadiene was qualifying income. Ethylene, you start going out into the fringes, and frankly for us to get into that business, we'd be competing with our customers, which probably is not the best business model, and it's frankly just not something that we have an interest in.
Great, that's very helpful. Thanks a lot, guys.
Your next question comes from the line of T. J. Shultz with RBC Capital Markets.

Hey, guys. Good morning. Just back to the onshore crude oil, I guess in the second half of last year, you really attributed the high margins to kind of two things, scarcity of trucks and then also the ability to buy on WTI and sell on LLS, now some of that went away in the first quarter, but bounced back this quarter. Just trying to gauge what you're seeing right now for the trucking and LLS opportunity as we move to the back half of this year?

I mean, trucking is not nearly as much in short supply as it was a year ago. And so we don't see the logistics in the South Texas and West Texas being as constrained as they were. In terms of the LLS pricing and WTI pricing going forward, the market of course sees that spread declining, which makes a lot of sense, but it's still pretty healthy and looks to be healthy through the end of the year.
Okay. On Seaway, do you have the mix of heavy versus light on the pipeline right now, and then any update on the timing for the expansion?

We don't have the mix. It's very early on. So we don't really know where that's going to be longer term. We certainly think it will be heavy and light moving. As far as expanding, we – I think we had mentioned in our write up, we will gradually expand over the next two years ultimately to a capacity of about 850.
I think we also said that we would have the pipeline fully reversed by the first quarter of next year.

And T. J., that 850 is kind of the theoretical capacity of the pipe assuming that it's up 365 days a year and it's – you're flowing in the right quality of crude to the extent that it's heavy or lighter as the volume change. So that's kind of a good ballpark number.
Okay. I guess just, then tying into ECHO, just an update on timing there on completion and then your bigger picture thoughts now on the potential to build out the storage there?

Yeah. The project is moving along very well. We expect that to be complete in September. We are talking to shippers and various folks in the industry who do have a strong demand for storage in the Houston area, and we think ECHO is a real good fit, and so do they. So we're optimistic that we'll see some storage revenue there.

We think ECHO has the potential to be a real jewel, T. J. And we have the plan that we can build out, what, 6.5 million barrels of storage on acreage we currently own. We have connectivity to every – we will have connectivity to every – pipe to every refinery in the Beaumont, Port Arthur, Houston area. So we're pretty excited about its future.

Okay, great. Maybe just one last one here, maybe for Randy. Just if you could comment on your financing thoughts, maybe balancing the liquidity you all have now versus the equity distribution agreement that was recently filed and maybe how you would expect to use that over time?
Equity distribution agreement?
Oh, the ATM facility?

Yeah, T. J., we finished the quarter with $3.1 billion worth of liquidity. So from our standpoint right now we've got a lot of flexibility on how we fund our growth. We did say early on this year that we did not have the need to issue equity, and if you would, that was really based on what we were seeing in the business environment in the first quarter and where our CapEx budget was in the first quarter.

Since then, we've, if you would, committed to the looping of Seaway, we've committed to the PDH unit, and while we're not really looking for a lot of CapEx this year with respect to those projects, it'll be more next year. The CapEx spend for next year is still announced (49:18). I think we still got flexibility with how we come in and finance growth for the remainder of this year, and – but we also don't want to get too far behind (49:28). As far as the ATM facility, again, that was a facility that, frankly, we've been looking forward to getting in place for a while. And the timing we've had an open window where we can come in and get that S-3 registration statement filed and (49:50)
Yeah, we did have a feature in one of our previous shelves that allowed a similar type of distribution of equity. We just never used it.
Great. Thanks, guys.
Your next question comes from the line of John Edwards with Credit Suisse.
Yeah. Good morning, everybody. I don't know if you spoke on this in your opening remarks, since we couldn't hear it either, but just any update on your thoughts on the distribution policy?

No. We've kind of been pretty consistent about that. And we talked about it in the last call. And what we said there was that we're going to reevaluate our distribution strategy towards the end of the year when more of our projects come online, so that's still our thought as we get into the fall, we'll take a look at it. And decide whether given our capital requirements, the financial market and our resources, whether it makes sense for us to perhaps be a little more aggressive on the distribution increases.

Okay. And then I'm just curious with, obviously we're seeing some increasing rejection of ethane, how that translates to the mix that gets fractionated on your system, if maybe you could talk a little bit about that?
Rudy, you want Rudy to take that?

Well, the fractionators are certainly have a design capacity based on a component structure, if we lose too much ethane capacity, we could lose fractionation capacity correspondingly. Of course, that gives us an opportunity if there's a spread between ethane and EP, go ahead and split EP, but it's a fairly wide range on the ethane percentage.
Okay.
Before you start losing capacity.
Yeah. Before you start losing capacity. That's true.
Okay. So you're not really seeing a significant change in the purity product that's coming out at this point, and you're not likely to?
No. A couple percent is really irrelevant to what we're doing.

Okay. All right, and then as far as the overall backlog of project opportunities, I guess Randy, you were saying you've got about $3.8 billion for the planned spend for 2013. What's the – I know Mike, last time you just said there's billions and billions of – where do you stand now on backlog of project opportunities?

John, I think if you look at some of our more recent presentations, we've got charts in there that show about $7 billion of projects under construction. And those are just the ones that we've announced, kind of big items. There's a number of smaller projects that we have that are not included in that list. So as Randy said before, kind of $3.8 billion in total for this year, $3.5 billion to $3.8 billion next year, and we've got assets that we're working to construct that will come in service 2014 or 2015. So I think if you're asking what is it beyond 2013?
Yeah.
I think $3 billion to $4 billion a year is a pretty safe bet.
Okay. All right, great. Thank you very much.
Your next question comes from the line of Harry Mateer with Barclays.
Hi, guys. I guess Randy, first question for you. You've got $500 million coming to you today, what are your plans for that?

We're going to pay it off. We'll come in and refinance that near-term, utilizing the flexibility that we've got under the credit facility and cash on hand. So, yeah Harry, that payment probably already went out this morning. And – but again, we've got a lot of flexibility as far as timing on when we come back in, and if you would refinance that in the term debt market.

Okay. And then second question, just given the declines we've seen in ethane and propane and the effects of those on the overall NGL barrel, are you guys seeing any sign of producers cutting back on drilling in liquids locations and if so, where in particular is that apparent?
I think primarily we've seen them cut back in dry locations. We haven't yet seen any cutback on, and if you look at the C3+ is still not a bad deal if you look historically.
Okay. So looking out to the balance of the year, you guys think that remains the same?
I think they're going to – it remains the same in terms of spread, yes.
And certainly, gas prices look better than they did a few months ago.
All right. Okay, great. That's it for me. Thank you.
Your next question comes from the line of Michael Blum with Wells Fargo.

Hi. Thank you. Just one more question on the propane de-hydro project, just trying to understand the nature of the contracts. I understand you said it, you'll have no commodity risk, but will you be getting demand, like take or pay demand charges on that or will it be volume times a fee? I'm just trying to understand how that's going to work from your end?
Go ahead, Gerry.
It's a processing fee, energy adjusted processing fee, on top of our propane cost with a deficiency fee embedded in that. So, yes, it's take or pay.
Okay. And then the customer is basically taking that spread risk?
That's correct.
Okay. Thank you.

Let's – I want to put it in a little bit more in context, think about it. These guys were buying their propylene from petrochemical companies that crack naphtha. Whenever – this project is really a shale gas project, driven by the consumers of propylene coming to the realization that they were buying a byproduct. What they're after now is a more secure source of supply that's more – that will be there every day, and they're willing to step up to that. And frankly, they believe in the future of the gas crude spread. They believe that ethane will be the base load and there'll be much less propylene coming out of the ethylene plants. Gerry?
That's correct.
Thank you, Jim.
Your next question will come from the line of John Tysseland with Citi.
Hi, guys. Good morning.
Hi, John.

Randy, quick question on the NGL hedges and kind of what you've seen over the last quarter with your counterparties. Given the swift move down, have you seen the liquidity in the forward market get reduced or dry up a little bit? And then also if you could just describe, in general, your counterparties that you have today.
Counterparties on the hedges?
Correct.
In a forward sense. (57:16)
Yes, NGLs is an interesting product, you can do a lot of physical forward selling on NGLs. I would say Al, most of our forward party forward sales are physical, to physical companies.
A combination.
We do some swaps, I guess, is what you're saying.
Yes.
So in other words, some banks are in there.
As far as the liquidity going forward, at these current spreads, we haven't been looking much going forward, but you can always go out about six months.
And John, are you focused more on liquidity or the credit quality of the counterparties or both?

Kind of both. I just didn't know what the forward market for being able to hedge in today's type of environment? I mean, it would appear that the counterparties in the last quarter probably got hit a little bit. And I just wanted to see what the current liquidity was for the forward market and who those counterparties were? But I mean, it sounds like most of your counterparties in this case are physical counterparties, not necessarily financial counterparties, is that fair?
I think what we're saying is they are both, what we're finding is there's fewer than there were before.
Yes, okay.
And John, then on the credit side, Randy and Brian have a pretty rigorous exercise they go through evaluating credit exposure and allocating that amongst our various business units.
And Randy and Brian work very close with our commercial folks. It's a heck of a team as it relates to credit. We're pretty tight on credit.

Yes, and John, I guess the one thing to add is probably the, if you've seen, I don't even want to say that you've seen a step change the first half of this year. But it's nothing compared to the step change that you saw coming out of 2008, 2009 with respect to liquidity and the number of parties that were there to come in and do forward sales of (59:24)
That's a great context. Thanks.
And at this time, there are no further questions. I will now turn the conference back over to management.

Regina, normally we ask for replay information. Given the poor quality of this call, I hesitate to do that, but I guess people can listen to the Q&A. So why don't you go ahead and give the information for the replay, and again, I'll – when we get the transcript, we'll have that posted on the website. Thank you, Regina.

Thank you. This conference will be available for replay in approximately two hours. The replay dial-in number is 855-859-2056, with conference ID number 11730222. Again, the number to dial for the replay is 855-859-2056, and entering conference ID number 11730222. This does conclude today's meeting. Thank you all for joining. And you may now disconnect.
Thank you.
You're welcome.
Have a good day.
You too.
